Ni stabilized over zirconia-alumina support (10Ni/10ZrAl), and further enhanced with gallium promotion, was examined for its efficacy in dry reforming of methane. 1–3 wt % gallium addition to the 10Ni/10ZrAl catalyst led to an even distribution of gallium throughout the catalyst, increased formation of NiO species that are easily reduced, and deposition of less graphitic carbon compared to an unpromoted catalyst. 10Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst has least carbon deposition and highest H2 yield (26 %) at 600 °C. Process optimization is performed over best catalyst, 10Ni2Ga/10ZrAl, by varying space velocity from 30,000 cm3 g−1h−1 to 48,000 cm3g−1h−1, reaction temperature from 550 °C to 800 °C, and CH4/CO2 from 0.5 to 1. A regression model equation is set as the function of factors, and the response as H2 yield through research surface methodology under center composite design. The model predicted an optimal H2 yield of 91.95 % which is closely validated by 90.09 % H2 yield experimental at optimized conditions. Graphical Abstract Keywords Dry reforming of methane Gallium promoter H2 yield Zirconia-alumina support Process optimization Research surface methodology Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The earth is warming at a rate of 0.2 °C per decade [1] and it is a direct threat to the existence of biological creatures on Earth in the future. Even now, global warming brings instant seasonal changes [2], extreme weather events like heat waves [3], rise of sea level [4] and low agriculture productivity [5]. The main culprits of global warming are greenhouse gases like CH4 and CO2. To tackle this challenge, the catalytic conversion of greenhouse gases into non-greenhouse gases has drawn much attention. In particular, dry reforming of methane reaction converts two global warming gases, CH4 and CO2, into syngas (H2+CO). That means this reaction gives way to depleting greenhouse gases and provides an opportunity to encompass future hydrogen energy goals. Noble metal and Ni are more reliable active catalysts (than Co and Fe) for DRM, but when it comes to cost, Ni has gained major acceptance [6]. The dispersion of Ni over proper support brings the stability of active sites, and it drew the size of Ni from bulk to nano level, which ultimately increase the population of active sites on the surface. Further use of second metal oxide as promoter over supported Ni catalyst may influence the reducibility, basicity, and coke resistance capacity of the catalyst in favour of DRM. As support, alumina is most trusted for support due to its thermal stability, high Ni dispersion, and cheapness. Alumina's inherent acidity weakens its interaction with acidic gases like CO2. Again, migration of active site Ni into the alumina lattice is easily evident, which may result in the loss of surface-active sites. The formation of zirconia-alumina support and then after the dispersion of Ni over zirconia-alumina support was found to enhance the activation of CO2 at Zr3+−oxygen vacancy [7] and prevent the diffusion of Ni into alumina lattice [8]. The presence of zirconia also enables lattice oxygen to participate in oxidation reactions like carbon deposit oxidation over the surface. So, as a support, zirconia-modified alumina may be a good choice for supporting Ni particles. As a promoter, Ga has the same size as alumina, so it may closely interact with alumina as well as it may introduce additional surface properties into the catalyst. The Ga2O3 is photo-catalytically active for CO2 conversion (into CO), methane oxidative coupling of methane (into ethane), and DRM [9–11]. Ni0.8Ga0.2 alloy induced the rate of CH4 decomposition [12]. A computational study showed that after CH4 decomposition, Ni3Ga alloy actively engages carbon by forming Ni3GaC0.25, which is oxidized into CO further by CO2. That means carbon is never left free for self-polymerization or carbon deposition [13]. Ga-Ni alloy was found to activate H2, which enables metallic phases to retain long [14]. The promotional addition of Ga over the “silicates supported Ni” catalyst retarded the coke formation due to the activation of adsorbed CO2 [15]. Ga addition over MCM-41 supported Ni catalyst was also found to reduce the coke deposition [16]. Addition of Ga was found to enhance the metal support interaction over lanthana-zirconia supported Ni catalyst [17]. After achieving catalytic excellence, the next goal is to carry out process optimization of reaction parameters to get the highest response of catalytic activity. In this regard, one factor at a time (OFAT) and response surface methodology (RSM) are two such processes that are used frequently by several research groups working in the field of DRM [18–21]. OFAT is a monovarietal process optimization whereas RSM is a multivariate process optimization. OFAT is unable to find the interaction between process parameters but RSM includes the interaction terms in the process parameters [22,23]. Herein, a zirconia-modified-alumina supported Ni catalyst is prepared, and further, it is promoted with 1–3 wt % Ga promoters. The catalytic activity is evaluated towards DRM. The catalytic activity results are validated by different characterization like X-ray diffraction, surface area and porosity, Raman spectroscopy, H2-temperature programmed reduction (TPR), CO2-temperature programmed desorption (TPD) and H2TPR-CO2TPD-H2TPR cyclic experiments. The best catalyst is further subjected to optimization of results through a surface methodology (RSM). The closeness between prediction results and experimental findings validates the applicability of theoretical models. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials Ni (NO3)2.6 H2O (Fisher, Germany), Ga (NO3)3.6 H2O (Fisher, Germany), and 10ZrO2+Al2O3 micro-spheres (dp = 400–500 μm; Daiichi Kigenso Kagaku Kogyo Co., Ltd.) were used to prepare the catalysts. 10ZrAl has been selected as a code for labeling the support 10ZrO2+Al2O3. As per the specification, the surface area of 10ZrAl support is 124 m2/g surface area, and it is populated with tetragonal ZrO2 and cubic Al2O3 phases. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 5 wt % nickel and 1–3 wt % gallium is incorporated into 10ZrAl by impregnation method. Nickel nitrate solution (equivalent to 5 wt % Ni) and gallium nitrate solution (equivalent to 1–3 wt %) are added to 10ZrAl support while stirring and heating. The mixture is held in an 80°C bath with moderate stirring until it evaporates. It is then dried overnight at 110 °C before being calcined for 300 min at 600 °C (heating ramp 1 °C/min). The prepared catalysts are abbreviated as 5Ni/10ZrAl, 5Ni0.5Ga/10ZrAl, 5Ni1Ga/10ZrAl, 5Ni1.5Ga/10ZrAl, 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl and 5Ni3Ga/10ZrAl. 2.3 Catalyst characterization The supplementary file contains detailed descriptions of the catalyst's characterizations under the S1. 2.4 Catalyst activity test A catalyst sample (0.1 g) was packed in a tubular stainless steel fixed-bed reactor (PID Eng & Tech, 9 mm I.D.). The reactor's temperature is monitored by a K-type thermocouple fitted axially at the center of the catalyst bed. Before the reaction, the catalyst was reduced by hydrogen at a 30 ml/min flow rate for 1 h at 800 °C. Afterward, the reactor was purged with N2 to remove the hydrogen gas from the system. Then, the temperature of the reactor is stabilized at 600 °C. The DRM reaction was carried out at a pressure of 1 atm and a temperature of 600°C over a reduced catalyst by using CH4 (flow rate 30 ml/min), CO2 (flow rate 30 ml/min), and N2 (flow rate 10 ml/min) feed gas mixture. For the optimization, the reaction temperatures, space velocities, the CH4/CO2 ratios were varied from 550 °C to 800 °C, 30,000 cm3g−1h−1 to 48,000 cm3g−1h−1, and 0.5–1 CH4/CO2 respectively. The product is analyzed by a gas chromatograph equipped with a proper Q column, molecular sieve columns, and a thermal conductivity detector. All catalysts show type IV adsorption isotherm with an H1 hysteresis loop, characteristic of cylindrical mesopores. For pore size analysis, a desorption branch is recommended for the H1 hysteresis loop [27]. The dV/dlogW vs W plot (V and W are pore volume and pore width) also shows monomodal pore size distribution where pore volume is majorly contributed by pore size of range ∼19 nm (Inset figures in Fig. 1). The average pore size over unpromoted catalyst (5Ni/10ZrAl) is found 15.6 nm whereas in Ga promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst the average pore size is increased nominally to 15.8–16.0 nm (Table 1). The unpromoted catalyst has 109 m2/g surface area, 0.53 cm3/g, and 15.6 nm pore diameter. After adding 0.5 wt % Ga over 5Ni/10ZrAl, the surface area and pore volume increase substantially (Table 1). It indicates that Ga is incorporated into the framework of 10ZrAl and that the framework is expanded. The highest expansion of surface parameters is noticed upon the addition of 2 wt % Ga over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst. 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst has 124 m2/g surface area, 0.61 cm3/g pore volume and 16 nm pore size. The X-ray diffraction pattern of 5Ni/10ZrAl and 5NixGa/10ZrAl (x = 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst is populated with cubic ZrO2 phase (at Bragg’s angle 2θ = 30.3 ̊, 50.6 ̊, 60.5 ̊; JCPDS reference number 00–027–0997), cubic aluminium-nickel phase (at Bragg’s angle 2θ = 50.6 ̊, 60.5 ̊; JCPDS reference number 00–044–1186) and crystalline cubic Al2O3 phase (at Bragg’s angle 2θ = 37.1 ̊, 46.2 ̊, 66.9 ̊; JCPDS reference number 00–004–0858) (Fig. S1 and Fig. 2A). In spent 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, the crystallinity of the catalyst gets down and an intense crystalline hexagonal graphitic carbon phase is observed additionally (at Bragg’s angle 2θ = 26.2 ̊; JCPDS reference number 01–075–1621) (Fig. S1). The 1–3 wt % Ga promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst has a similar diffraction pattern, and no Ga-related phases are observed. It indicates that the promotor gallium is well dispersed over the catalyst surface. The intensity of the AlNi alloy phase is found to be at its maximum over 1.5 wt % Ga promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst (Fig. 2 B). The Raman spectra of fresh 5Nix/10ZrAl (x = 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalysts are shown in Fig. 2C. As reported previously, alumina doesn’t give rise to Raman bands in this spectrum [28–30]. The presence cubic phase of ZrO2 is again varified by intense Raman spectra at 147 cm−1 and 278 cm−1 [31,32]. It is interesting to note that at 2 wt % Ga loading over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, the Raman band at 147 cm−1 fades up (Fig. 2D). It indicates that Ga introduction affects one of the vibration modes of cubic ZrO2 Raman band. The Raman spectra for Ni-O vibrations are coupled with the vibration of alumina support. The Raman peaks of about 493 cm−1 and 660 cm−1 are attributed to the T2 g and A1 g vibration mode of NiO over Al2O3 [33,34]. T2 g and A1 g vibration mode of NiO in NiAl2O4 are also observed at 564 cm−1 and 866 cm−1 respectively [34]. These observations indicate that NiO is majorly interacted with Al2O3 in zirconia-alumina support. Again, the dispersed nanodomain of NiAl2O4 is also present over the catalyst surface, which remains undetected by XRD. H2-temperature programmed reduction profile of 5Ni/10ZrAl and 5NixGa/10ZrAl (x = 0, 1, 1.5, 2 wt %) catalysts are shown in Fig. 3 A. The negative value in H2-TPR around 200 °C is due to hydrogen spill over into the mesopores [35]. The reduction profile of the catalyst is based on the extent of reduction of “surface interacted NiO species” against temperature. It shows a diffuse reduction peak at 550 °C and an intense reduction peak at about 850 °C. The first peak is the attribution of such NiO species, which interacted with support with moderate interaction. In contrast, the second peak signifies those NiO species that strongly interacted with support [35]. The “strongly interacted NiO species” are harder to reduce than the “moderately interacted NiO species.” The absence of a reduction peak below 400 °C indicates that the weakly interacted NiO or free NiO species are absent over the catalyst surface. An unpromoted catalyst has a lower concentration of “strongly interacted NiO,” whereas a gallium-promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst has a higher concentration of strongly interacted NiO. Over the fresh catalyst, the change in reduction profile is not evident upon different gallium loading over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst. After reduction under H2, “metallic Ni” is surged over the catalyst as an active site for CH4 decomposition. Further, as per the basicity of the reduced catalyst surface, CO2 interacts with the catalyst surface and oxidizes the dissociated CH4. So, the basic profile of reduced catalyst needs to be addressed. The CO2-TPD of spent catalysts are shown in Fig. 3B. The CO2 desorption profile of unpromoted catalyst is mainly constituted by a sharp peak of about 105 °C and a broad peak of about 290 °C. These are attributed to weak basic sites and moderate strength basic sites, respectively. The unpromoted catalyst surface has a significant density of mild-strength basic sites. Interestingly, upon Ga loading over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, the second desorption peak profile is shifted to a higher temperature (430 °C), as well as the intensity of the peak is also decreased. This peak can be regarded as a strong basic site. These results need a more deliberate discussion. Generally, weak basic sites, moderate strength basic sites, and strong basic sites are attributed to surface hydroxyl, surface oxide ions, and surface decomposable carbonates, respectively [35]. That means unpromoted catalyst (5Ni/10ZrAl) bears basicity mainly by surface hydroxyl and surface oxide ions. However, upon adding Ga over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, the density of surface oxide ion is depleted, and surface decomposable carbonates are populated over the catalyst surface. So, basicity over 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl is constituted by surface hydroxyl (weak primary sites) and surface decomposable carbonates (strong basic sites). It should be noted that upon variation in loading of Ga over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, the change in basic profile is not evident. The reduction profile of the catalyst keeps changing under an oxidizing gas stream (which is also one of the substrates of DRM) and a reducing gas stream (which is one of the products of DRM). CO2 can oxidize the active “metallic Ni” sites into NiO, whereas H2 can further reduce the NiO into metallic Ni again. Under the continuum of CO2 and H2 during DRM, the reduction profile of the catalyst keeps on changing. To understand this, we have carried out the H2TPR-CO2TPD-H2TPR cycle in continuation in the target of reducing surface NiO species into Ni (by first H2-TPR), then oxidation of active sites into NiO (by CO2 TPD) and finally reduction of NiO into Ni (by last H2TPR) (Fig. 3C-E, Fig. S2). Under the first H2-TPR; hydrogen is adsorbed by the catalyst against temperature rise (up to 1000 °C at 10°C/min heating ramp) which results in the reduction of NiO into Ni by losing nearby oxygen and leaving oxygen vacancy behind. Further, the temperature of the catalyst is decreased to 50°C, and then after 10 %CO2/He mixture is allowed to pass through catalyst. The vacancies are replenished by oxygen (of CO2) and in this way, Ni is oxidized into NiO again. The greater the extent of replenishment of oxygen into the vacancy, the higher will be the possibility of oxidation of metal into metal oxide. Now, the temperature of the catalyst is risen to 1000°C (with a 10°C/min heating ramp) so that CO2 can be desorbed and the surface is cleaned before initiating the last H2-TPR. Finally, the last H2-TPR is carried out. Notably, the percentage of total reducible NiO is decreased during reduction-oxidation-reduction treatment. Over 5Ni/10ZrAl, total reducible NiO remains 63 %. Upon increasing Ga loading up to 1–2 wt %, it further drops 33 % (Table S1). After this reduction-oxidation-reduction treatment, the reduction profile is also modified and the reduction peak is localized between about 200°C and 830°C (Fig. 3F). The reduction peak of about 200 °C belongs to “weakly interacted NiO” [35] which is easy to reduce. The unpromoted catalyst has a higher concentration of “strongly interacted NiO species” than the rest catalyst. Strongly interacted NiO species are harder to reduce. It is noticeable that an unpromoted catalyst has just 8 % more easily reducible NiO than the total reducible NiO amount (Table S1). Upon increasing gallium loading, the percentage of easily reducible NiO is increased. 5Ni1Ga/10ZrAl, 5Ni1.5Ga/10ZrAl and 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl contain 14 %, 34 % and 38 % easily reducible NiO respectively. The Raman spectra of spent-5Nix/10ZrAl (x = 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalysts are shown in Fig. 4A. All catalysts have Raman carbon band at 1347 cm−1, 1580 cm−1 and 2671 cm−1 which are attributed to defect carbon band (D band), graphitic carbon band (G band) and 2D second-order band. The ID/IG ratio is minimal over an unpromoted catalyst (ID/IG = 1.1), indicating a high degree of graphitization. After adding Ga promotor over 5Ni/10ZrAl, the ID/IG ratio is increased greatly. The ID/IG ratio is found to be maximum over 5Ni1.5Ga/10ZrAl catalyst, indicating minimum graphitization. The 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst has a double ID/IG ratio than the unpromoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, indicating half graphitization over 2 wt % Ga promoted catalyst than the unpromoted catalyst. The thermogravimetry profile of 5Ni/10ZrAl and 5NixGa/10ZrAl (x = 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalysts is shown in Fig. 4B. The TGA result shows that the 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst has minimum weight loss (18.16 %), whereas 5Ni/ZrAl undergoes huge weight loss (35.43 %). The weight loss over different spent catalysts is found in the following order: 5Ni/10ZrAl> 5Ni0.5Ga/10ZrAl> 5Ni1.5 G/10ZrAl> 5Ni1Ga/10ZrAl> 5Ni3Ga/10ZrAl. The transmission electron microscopy (TEM) image and particle size distribution are presented in Fig. 5. This image shows the 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst following a 10-hour reaction at 800°C reaction temperature. The analysis of this image reveals that the catalyst particles have a size of approximately 12 nanometres. 3.2 Activity results and discussion The catalytic activity of 5Ni/10ZrAl and 5NixGa/10ZrAl (x = 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalyst in terms of H2 yield is shown in Fig. 6 A. At 600 °C reaction temperature, 42,000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity and CH4/CO2 ratio 1, the effect of promoter over H2 yield during 300 min time on stream is evident over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst. Gallium is finely dispersed over 5NixGa/10ZrAl (x = 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 3) catalyst. The surface area and pore volume of the Ga-promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst are higher than that of the unpromoted catalyst. Gallium presence perturbs some of the vibration modes of cubic-ZrO2, which indicates the close interaction of Ga with ZrO2. Upon gallium promotional addition, the basicity profile over the catalysts shifts from “moderate basic sites” to “strong basic sites.” During the DRM reaction, the gallium-promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst attains a relatively higher percentage of easily reducible NiO. After the reducibility and basicity, the role of deposited carbon becomes important. The carbon having a higher degree of graphitization is hard to oxidize as well, and there is the possibility of hindering the active sites by this carbon. Both may affect the activity adversely. Unpromoted spent catalyst (5Ni/10ZrAl) has the highest degree of graphitization, and its TGA profile shows huge weight loss. Overall, the unpromoted catalyst (5Ni/10ZrAl) has an initial 21 % H2 yield, which slows down to 11 % at the end of 300 min. The 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst has a strong interaction of Ga and Zr. The degree of graphitization of 2 wt % Ga promoted 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst is half that of the unpromoted catalyst; it has minimum coke deposition and attains the highest H2-yield. Upon 0.5 wt %, 1 wt %, 1.5 wt %, 2 wt % Ga loading over 5Ni/10ZrAl catalyst, the initial H2-yield is increased to 23 %, 24 %, 25 % and 26 % respectively. At the end of 300 min on stream also, H2 yield over 5Ni0.5Ga/10ZrAl, 5Ni1Ga/10ZrAl, 5Ni1.5Ga/10ZrAl, and 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl, are observed at 14 %, 15 %, 16 % and 17 % respectively. The temperature effect over 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst is also studied and presented in Fig. 6B. Upon the rise of reaction temperature from 550 to 800 °C, the H2 yield rises from 12.71 % to 76.45 % at 30,000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity and CH4/CO2 ratio 1. The rise in catalytic activity upon the rise of temperature is evident due to the endothermic nature of the DRM reaction. Again, at low-temperature DRM reaction, the coke deposition due to CO disproportionation reaction is highly feasible thermodynamically [36], resulting in an inferior activity. Upon increasing the temperature, such a reaction becomes infeasible, which results in more exposure to active sites and higher activity towards DRM. In the target of achieving higher H2-yield over 5Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst, different reaction parameters (space velocity, reaction temperature, and CH4/CO2 ratio) are varied, a statistical model is set, optimum values of H2 yield are predicted, and finally, the statistical results are verified by practical results in the next section. 3.3 Prediction and optimization processes The three experimental factors or reaction parameters (xi; i = 1,2,3), namely space velocity (30,000 cm3cg−1h−1, 39,000 cm3g−1h−1, 48,000 cm3g−1h−1), temperature (550 °C, 675 °C, 800 °C) and CH4/CO2 ratio (0.5, 0.75, 1) are considered for the design of experiment. The center point of the design of each process parameter (experiment factors) is changed into a code dimensionless variable, as shown in Table 2. The system response is collected as a function of factor by Eq. 5. The high F-value (fisher variation) and P-value < 0.05 indicate the significance of the model within the 95 % confidence limit. At a level of significance ( α = 0.05(, Fcal. (calculated value) < Fcrit. (critical value) or P-value < 0.05 indicates the fitting of experimental data with the regression model. The high value of R2 also indicates the goodness-of-fit of the models with experiment data under a 0–100 scale. The analysis of variance and prediction statistics ( Table 3 ) are calculated to check the fitness of the regression models. After excluding the insignificant factors, a simplified Eq. (8) is presented using the Design-Expert software package version 13. Table 4 shows the experimental response of H2 yield % and the predicted response of H2 yield and error %. After 90 min on stream, the experimental H2 yield for the modeling of the program was calculated, taking into account an average value of three readings. Fig. 7 represents the plot of the predicted and the actual values of the response variables. The R2 = 0.9987 and MAPEs = 2.12 indicate the goodness of fitting and closeness between the expected response and the precise response of H2-yield %. The closeness between the estimated responses from the fitted model and the actual values is evident in the small absolute error rates for each case, where the mean absolute error percentage MAPE = 2.12 for the fitted model of H2 Yield %. (8) Y H 2 ˆ % = − 396.94251 + 1.00778 * the T + 0.000919 * SV + 47.142 * CH 4 / CO 2 − 0.000002 * T * SV − 0.0972 * T * CH 4 / CO 2 − 0.00044 * T ² With the aid of Eq. 8, the response surface plots were constructed for the predicted formation of the components comprising the reaction system versus one process variable (by keeping the other two factors constant) and two process variables (by keeping the third-factor constant). The effect of process parameters on the reaction responses is shown as a one-factor effect (2D) in Fig. 8 and a two-factor effect (3D) in Figs. 9–10 , respectively. Fig. 8 shows the one-factor effect indicating that increasing temperature, decreasing the GHSV value, and decreasing the CH4/ CO2 ratio will increase H2 yield %. Fig. 9 shows the surface plots, representing the functional relationship between the designated response variable and the two factors variables (Temperature and gas hour space velocity) with a CH4: CO2 feed ratio fixed at 0.605. The response surface shows that H2 yield % increases with temperature increase and decreases the GHSV. It was observed to increase from 9.25 % at 550 °C to 91.95 % at 800 °C. Fig. 10 shows the surface plots that represent the functional relationship between the designated response variable (H2 yield %), and the two-factor variables (Temperature and CH4: CO2) with GHSV fixed at 30,000 cm3g−1h−1. The response surface shows that the H2 yield % increases upon increasing the temperature and decreasing the ratio of CH4: CO2. The Optimization process was done by maximizing the response variables (H2 yield %) using design experiment version 13, which has the optimization goals. Hence, it gives many solutions that fit the required goals and selects the optimum conditions based on the solution with the highest value of the desirability function. Each set of the process conditions, Temperature, GHSV, and CH4: CO2, was subjected to the model present in Eq. 8 to obtain predicted goals in Table 5. The validation results of the experimental condition are also presented in Table 5. This close agreement between experiment and prediction strengthens our confidence in the underlying theoretical model, which can guide future research. Optimization isn't about creating a perfect solution, it's about getting things to a good enough level that meets all the goals. 4 Conclusion The introduction of Ga into the 10Ni/10ZrAl catalyst nurtures strong basic sites and a relatively higher amount of easily reducible NiO during the DRM reaction. The type of carbon deposit over gallium-promoted Ni/10ZrAl is also less graphitic. At optimum 2 wt % gallium loading over 10Ni/10ZrAl catalyst at 600 °C, the highest 26 % initial H2 yield and minimum carbon are noticed. At 30,000 cm3g−1h−1 space velocity, H2 yield varied from ∼12–76 % upon raising the reaction temperature from 550 °C to 800 °C due to the endothermic nature of the reaction and thermodynamic infeasibility of major coke deposition reaction via CO disproportionation reaction. Over 10Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst, the various H2-yeild is collected as response variables by varying the reaction parameter/factors like space velocity from 30,000 cm3g−1h−1 to 48,000 cm3g−1h−1, reaction temperature from 550 °C to 800 °C temperature and 0.5–1 CH4/CO2. The fitness of the regression model is examined by ANOVA and simplified by Design-Expert software package version 13. The model predicted an optimal H2 yield of 91.95 % over 10Ni2Ga/10ZrAl at 799.96°C temperature, 0.5 CH4/CO2 ratio, and 30,019.75 cm3g⁻¹h⁻¹ gas hourly space velocity. However, experimental validation under these conditions yielded an H2 yield of 90.09 %. The experimental finding is close to the prediction results, which indicates the validity of theoretical models. coredata.dc:description: Ni stabilized over zirconia-alumina support (10Ni/10ZrAl), and further enhanced with gallium promotion, was examined for its efficacy in dry reforming of methane. 1–3 wt % gallium addition to the 10Ni/10ZrAl catalyst led to an even distribution of gallium throughout the catalyst, increased formation of NiO species that are easily reduced, and deposition of less graphitic carbon compared to an unpromoted catalyst. 10Ni2Ga/10ZrAl catalyst has least carbon deposition and highest H2 yield (26 %) at 600 °C. Process optimization is performed over best catalyst, 10Ni2Ga/10ZrAl, by varying space velocity from 30,000 cm3 g−1h−1 to 48,000 cm3g−1h−1, reaction temperature from 550 °C to 800 °C, and CH4/CO2 from 0.5 to 1. A regression model equation is set as the function of factors, and the response as H2 yield through research surface methodology under center composite design. The model predicted an optimal H2 yield of 91.95 % which is closely validated by 90.09 % H2 yield experimental at optimized conditions.
